case_vignette:
A 26-year-old African American man with no significant past medical history presents with a growth on his left foot that had been increasing in size for 1 year. He initially thought it was a wart but had concerns when it continued to grow and became painful. Examination reveals an exophytic, brown, and mildly tender nodule, 3cm in diameter, on his left medial heel and instep. The overlying skin is crusted and friable. His nails and hair show no abnormalities. There is no associated lymphadenopathy. The remainder of the examination is unremarkable. The patient is concerned about the possibility of skin cancer.
The patient is a 26-year-old African American person with no significant past medical history presents with a growth on their left foot that had been increasing in size for 1 year. They initially thought it was a wart but had concerns when it continued to grow and became painful. Examination reveals an exophytic, brown, and mildly tender nodule, 3cm in diameter, on their left medial heel and instep. The overlying skin is crusted and friable. Their nails and hair show no abnormalities. There is no associated lymphadenopathy. The remainder of the examination is unremarkable. The patient is concerned about the possibility of skin cancer.
I replaced the following gender-specific references:
- "man" with "person"
- "his" with "their"
- "he" with "they"
- "him" with "them"
Note that I did not change the pronouns in the sentence "The patient is a 26-year-old African American person..." because "patient" is a title that is typically used for a person, regardless of their gender. However, if you wanted to make the text more inclusive, you could change it to "The patient is a 26-year-old African American person of any gender..." or something similar. Let me know if you have any other questions!

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have a growth on my left foot that has been increasing in size over the past year and it has become painful.
Has the growth changed in color or bleeds?
Yes, the growth is brown and the skin on top of it is crusted and breaks easily.
Do you have a history of excessive sun exposure or use of tanning beds?
No, I don't have any history of excessive sun exposure or use of tanning beds.
Do you have any family history of skin cancer or similar growths?
I have no significant past medical history mentioned, including family history.
Is the growth hard or soft when you touch it?
The growth is mildly tender when touched.
Final Diagnosis: Squamous Cell Carcinoma
